stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on UV mapping and texturing the large, labyrinthine castle level (Course 13). Key discussions included a major performance breakthrough using the new FBDX3 microcode, the shift of the performance bottleneck to the RSP, his art workflow with Biobak, and the financial pressures of being a creator.

development_findings.summary: The team has successfully implemented FBDX3, a new microcode by contributor Sauraen, which has significantly improved the game's performance to nearly 60 FPS in demanding areas.
development_findings.quote: We got FBDX3 working correctly now... it's basically like 50 FPS now. And I haven't even limited the drawing distance again.

development_findings.summary: With the new FBDX3 microcode, Kaze has discovered that the performance bottleneck has shifted from memory traffic and the RDP to the RSP, a significant technical finding for optimized N64 development.
development_findings.quote: We found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor now, if you actually optimize your game well... At this point, I think that optimizing memory helps the RSP run well.

development_findings.summary: A public demo focusing only on the first level is planned to allow the community to test and provide feedback on the new player controls and camera system.
development_findings.quote: I'm planning a demo of just Course 1, only the first level. So everyone can play with the new camera and the new Mario controls.

development_findings.summary: The large, complex geometry of Course 13 is causing the game to exceed the memory limit for collision data, a temporary problem that will be resolved by implementing a proper collision map.
development_findings.quote: We are running out of memory for collision triangles. Yep, that sucks. It's only temporary because as soon as we make a collision map, that issue will go away.

development_findings.summary: Course 13 is designed to be a large, labyrinthine castle with multiple interconnected paths, shortcuts, and secret warps to encourage exploration.
development_findings.quote: There's a secret pipe here, and if you go into the pipe, you come out here... and now you're here, from a completely different angle. There's so many different ways to the castle.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a bug where ambient lighting disappears when Mario gets close to an additional light source, noting it only occurs with the X2 microcode on emulators.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states that since having a child, he needs to increase his income, which will lead to more frequent YouTube videos and potentially compromising his content for financial gain.
context_findings.quote: Now that I have a child, I need to make more money. So that means a lot more YouTube content. But it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes invoking specific emotions in the player (e.g., feeling 'cold and mysterious') over purely aesthetic appeal, which he considers a secondary concern.
context_findings.quote: When I'm doing visuals, I don't really think about it in terms of like pleasure to look at. That's like secondary to me. For me, I think about it in first line about like emotions I want to invoke in the player. And I want this to feel cold and mysterious.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a cynical view of YouTube's content trends, sarcastically outlining a plan to manufacture drama for views, which reveals his awareness and distaste for the platform's culture.
context_findings.quote: If you ever look at YouTube, all of YouTube right now is just this person's a pedophile, this person's a groomer. That is what's going well on YouTube. You just have to invent a pedophile to expose him. And then you get the views.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he is currently off work from his other job(s) because he and Zeina just had a child.

biobak.summary: Kaze defines his art and texturing work as a preliminary 'suggestion' for Biobak, who is responsible for refining the visuals and elevating them to their final quality.
biobak.quote: Really at this point I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

zeina.summary: Zeina is currently creating assets for the outside area of Course 13.
The personal and professional relationship between Kaze and Zeina is highlighted, as he mentions she will be cutting his hair after the stream.
zeina.quote: Yes, Zeina haircut. I'm not paying for a haircut. I'm making Zeina do it.

key_stories.title: The FBDX3 Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: The team faced significant performance issues in large levels. After implementing a new microcode (FBDX3) from contributor Sauraen, they not only achieved a near-60 FPS framerate but also made a key technical discovery that the performance bottleneck had shifted from the RDP to the RSP, changing their approach to optimization.
key_stories.challenge: The game's performance was struggling in large, complex levels, making a smooth frame rate seem unattainable.
key_stories.process: Contributor Sauraen developed a new, faster microcode called FBDX3. Kaze integrated it into the project. After initial troubleshooting where it seemed slower, he realized that by optimizing memory traffic so heavily, the bottleneck had shifted to the RSP, which the new microcode helps alleviate.
key_stories.outcome: The game now runs at nearly 60 FPS in previously demanding areas. This led to a new technical understanding: for highly optimized N64 games, the RSP becomes the primary bottleneck, not memory or fillrate as is commonly believed.
key_stories.key_quote: We found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor now... If you look at my performance counter on the N64, you can see that I'm still RSP bottlenecked. Even though I have a faster microcode now than X2 has.

key_stories.title: Art Direction as a 'Suggestion'
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled with the artistic direction for Course 13. He resolved this by defining a workflow where he creates placeholder art focused on conveying a specific emotion, which then acts as a visual and thematic 'suggestion' for the main artist, Biobak, to refine into the final product.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze, not being a specialized artist, needed to define the visual style for a new level (Course 13) but was struggling to create final-quality assets himself.
key_stories.process: Kaze worked on UV mapping and texturing the level, openly admitting his work looked 'terrible' and 'boring'. Instead of aiming for perfection, he focused on conveying a feeling. He explicitly stated that his work is a functional placeholder for Biobak to interpret and improve.
key_stories.outcome: A clear collaborative workflow was established. Kaze focuses on creating placeholder geometry and textures to establish the intended mood ('cold and mysterious'), which then serves as a detailed brief for the project's artist, Biobak, to build upon and finalize.
key_stories.key_quote: Really at this point I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

key_stories.title: The Pressure to 'Sell Out'
key_stories.summary: Facing new financial pressures as a parent, Kaze discussed his need to make more money. This led to a cynical brainstorming session where he outlined a satirical plan to exploit YouTube's drama-focused algorithm, revealing the conflict between his creative integrity and the financial realities of being a content creator.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needs to earn more money to support his family after the birth of his child.
key_stories.process: Kaze discussed his financial needs openly on stream. This led to him brainstorming YouTube video ideas, culminating in a sarcastic and elaborate plan to manufacture a controversy for views. This highlights the external pressures influencing his creative work.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze plans to increase his video output significantly. His cynical brainstorming reveals a deep understanding of and frustration with YouTube's algorithm and drama-driven culture, which he feels pressured by.
key_stories.key_quote: We make like the most clickbait videos ever. And then on this old account, we pretend to be a pedophile. And then on the main account, we expose the old account for being a pedophile. And we make it to the YouTube trends and get 2 million views.

open_questions.context: Kaze described his art as a 'suggestion' for Biobak, who then improves it. The specifics of this collaboration were not detailed.
questions: Can you walk me through the process of handing off a level to Biobak? What materials or instructions do you provide?
How much creative freedom does Biobak have to change your initial 'suggestion'?
Can you give an example of a time when Biobak's interpretation completely changed or elevated your original idea for a level's look and feel?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that implementing the FBDX3 microcode revealed that the RSP, not the RDP, is the new performance bottleneck for their highly optimized game.
questions: What was the 'aha' moment when you realized the bottleneck had shifted to the RSP?
How does this discovery change your approach to level design and optimization moving forward?
You mentioned another developer, Rionna, had a similar issue. How much of this was a collaborative discovery within the wider N64 dev community versus an isolated finding?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that Zeina is creating assets for the outside area of Course 13. He also mentioned they just had a child and she cuts his hair.
questions: How do you and Zeina collaborate on the game? Do you work in the same room or have formal check-ins?
How do you navigate giving and receiving creative feedback as spouses working on the same project?
How has having a child changed your daily development routine and collaboration?

open_questions.topic: Financial Realities of a Niche Creator
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned needing to make more money and having multiple 'online jobs' in addition to his ROM hacking and YouTube content.
questions: You mentioned needing to 'sell out a little bit'. What does that line look like for you? What would you not be willing to do?
How do you balance the time and energy between your passion projects like this game and the jobs that pay the bills?
What is the financial reality of being a full-time creator in the ROM hacking space? Is it sustainable on its own?
